trans-unit.target: Use the light sensor

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: Windows.Devices.Sensors
trans-unit.target: Windows.Devices.Sensors

trans-unit.source: LightSensor
trans-unit.target: LightSensor

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the ambient light sensor to detect changes in lighting.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the ambient light sensor to detect changes in lighting.

trans-unit.source: An ambient light sensor is one of the several types of environmental sensors that allow apps to respond to changes in the user's environment.
trans-unit.target: An ambient light sensor is one of the several types of environmental sensors that allow apps to respond to changes in the user's environment.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C\#, and events.
trans-unit.target: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C\#, and events.

trans-unit.source: The device or emulator that you're using must support an ambient light sensor.
trans-unit.target: The device or emulator that you're using must support an ambient light sensor.

trans-unit.source: Create a simple light-sensor app
trans-unit.target: Create a simple light-sensor app

trans-unit.source: This section is divided into two subsections.
trans-unit.target: This section is divided into two subsections.

trans-unit.source: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple light-sensor application from scratch.
trans-unit.target: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple light-sensor application from scratch.

trans-unit.source: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.
trans-unit.target: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.

trans-unit.source: Instructions
trans-unit.target: Instructions

trans-unit.source: Create a new project, choosing a **Blank App (Universal Windows)** from the **Visual C\#** project templates.
trans-unit.target: Create a new project, choosing a **Blank App (Universal Windows)** from the **Visual C\#** project templates.

trans-unit.source: Open your project's BlankPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.
trans-unit.target: Open your project's BlankPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you created a project named **LightingCS**, you'd replace `namespace App1` with `namespace LightingCS`.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you created a project named **LightingCS**, you'd replace `namespace App1` with `namespace LightingCS`.

trans-unit.source: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.
trans-unit.target: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you created a project named **LightingCS**, you'd replace `x:Class="App1.MainPage"` with `x:Class="LightingCS.MainPage"`.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you created a project named **LightingCS**, you'd replace `x:Class="App1.MainPage"` with `x:Class="LightingCS.MainPage"`.

trans-unit.source: You should also replace `xmlns:local="using:App1"` with `xmlns:local="using:LightingCS"`.
trans-unit.target: You should also replace `xmlns:local="using:App1"` with `xmlns:local="using:LightingCS"`.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 or select **Debug** > **Start Debugging** to build, deploy, and run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 or select **Debug** > **Start Debugging** to build, deploy, and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Once the app is running, you can change the light sensor values by altering the light available to the sensor or using the emulator tools.
trans-unit.target: Once the app is running, you can change the light sensor values by altering the light available to the sensor or using the emulator tools.

trans-unit.source: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select **Debug** > **Stop Debugging** to stop the app.
trans-unit.target: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select **Debug** > **Stop Debugging** to stop the app.

trans-unit.source: Explanation
trans-unit.target: Explanation

trans-unit.source: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate light-sensor input in your app.
trans-unit.target: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate light-sensor input in your app.

trans-unit.source: The app establishes a connection with the default sensor in the **BlankPage** method.
trans-unit.target: The app establishes a connection with the default sensor in the **BlankPage** method.

trans-unit.source: The app establishes the report interval within the **BlankPage** method.
trans-unit.target: The app establishes the report interval within the **BlankPage** method.

trans-unit.source: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).
trans-unit.target: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).

trans-unit.source: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.
trans-unit.target: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.

trans-unit.source: The new light-sensor data is captured in the **ReadingChanged** method.
trans-unit.target: The new light-sensor data is captured in the **ReadingChanged** method.

trans-unit.source: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the value to your app using this event handler.
trans-unit.target: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the value to your app using this event handler.

trans-unit.source: The app registers this event handler on the following line.
trans-unit.target: The app registers this event handler on the following line.

trans-unit.source: These new values are written to a TextBlock found in the project's XAML.
trans-unit.target: These new values are written to a TextBlock found in the project's XAML.
